awd_titl_txt: SCH: EXP: Smart integration of community crowdsourced data for real-time individualized disease risk assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses a major inefficiency in healthcare today: an under-informed, homogeneous approach to patient care that doesn't consider community disease prevalence and its effect on an individual's disease risk in an actionable manner. The approach is to combine real-time diagnostic information from select community members via an easy to use, gargle-based immunoassay detection test with more abundant contemporaneous community symptom reports via an online informatics platform. The hypothesis is that the likelihood of a virological diagnosis of influenza (flu) can be accurately predicted for the individual using real-time flu self-diagnostics and symptom information from their community, and can influence a user to take appropriate measures to prevent disease spread. This approach enables testing of several concepts regarding (1) the specificity and sensitivity of a rapid flu diagnostic test for Influenza A and B detection compared to a laboratory polymerase chain reaction test, (2) generation of valid user-contributed diagnostic information at scale (3), potential of real-time contextual data to be used to calculate influenza risk, (4) use and acceptance of this information by individuals. The team brings together experience in building and studying novel crowdsourced data sources for disease surveillance and expertise in software, graphic design, epidemiology, medicine, and engineering, to develop user-friendly systems that the community will employ at scale.

The proposed system has substantial potential for beneficial societal impact through acertaining and changing the way people approach healthcare. Empowering individuals to generate and act on health information impresses on them the importance of surveillance and educates them to become more involved and accountable for their health. In order to maximize the impact and sustainability of the system, this system also functions as an educational tool. Clear open communication of anonymized and privacy-protected data to the general public in an easy to interpret manner will assist individuals, policy-makers and other researchers in using contextual disease risk information. Undergraduate and graduate students from a variety of backgrounds will have opportunity to participate in the research. Collaborators at the American Public Health Association and their associated groups concerned with the health of minority populations such as The Association of Minority Health Professions Schools and The Latina Health Project will assist in engaging a diverse group of participants nationwide.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project generated and assessed community-sourced multi-modal data for infectious disease surveillance and prediction. Our work focused on acute respiratory infections (ARIs) which result in tens of thousands of hospitalizations and deaths annually, costing billions in direct medical expenses as well as in lost earnings. Community-sourced (participatory, citizen-science or crowdsourced) data is an important to consider for infection prediction and forecasting, as data from clinical systems generally represents only the most severe cases of ARIs and models built on those data only are limited in generalizability. Further, there are open methodological questions regarding analyzing unstructured, multi-modal and noisy Internet and mobile sourced data, in order to best harness their benefits of precise geo-referencing and real-time nature.

We built an Internet and mobile reporting platform, and over multiple flu seasons recruited a diverse set of participants. We linked collected demographic and symptom information through the season from individuals, and via molecular specimens, ascertained what type of virus those who got sick had using gold standard laboratory methods. Once information was collated, we produced visualizations to share aggregate information back to individuals. We analyzed the participatory data for predictive value, multi-modal inference and identified new research approaches for observational data. Participants were surveyed to assess their willingness and incentives to participate.

Basic science outcomes from the work include development of a pipeline for sourcing community generated molecular specimens in combination with linked symptom and demographic information, comparison of different specimen types for ARI detection, analysis of Bayesian network inference methods for multi-modal data, and assessed the predictive value  of participatory data using different machine learning methods.

Our results demonstrated that community-submitted specimens can be used for the detection of acute respiratory infection. In terms of citizen-science efforts, ours was the first to show that the public can generate and contribute diagnostic specimens on their own, during illness. Our post-study surveys also indicated that individuals show receptivity for participating in and gaining a real-time picture of respiratory pathogens near them. Analyses from this work confirmed symptom profiles used in clinical prediction tools are also good predictors of ARI in the community, but found that clinical data may overestimate this due to sampling bias.

Through the public-facing nature of the work, thousands of participants (mostly from the northeast United States) were involved and thus informed about disease surveillance and data efforts. We also exposed, informed and inspired hundreds of students through high school and other outreach efforts, regarding the potential of data-driven efforts in health.  

Above and beyond these specific results, the work helped distill new research questions regarding for person-generated observational data. Broadly, this project will have implications for the fields of disease modeling and public health and we anticipate results will inform precision and personalized public health and medicine efforts. Building on this research has also spurred new work regarding user experience and participation in knowledge generation of public health data. We anticipate further outcomes resulting from analysis of the generated data including contrasting it with data collected through other mechanisms.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2017
Modified by: Rumi Chunara
